comment: Abbi (2006) and (2013) doesn't provide any forms for 1st and 2nd person plural possessor pronouns. Because there are singular possessive forms different to the argument marking pronouns, it is highly likely there are plural forms. I have entered the argument marking pronouns in the plural possessor cells in order not to have empty cells.
ni, ŋa were presented in Abbi 2006.  ŋu is presented in Abbi 2013.
naŋe is 2sg. honorific.  naŋela, ŋoli, ŋamboro are 2du honorific. ŋale, ŋele are 2pl honorific. (Abbi2013).
ŋu appears to be for inalienable possession, ɲe is for alieanble possession.
ɖu is 3sg distant, visible. u~o is 3sg distant, invisible. kʰudi is 3sg proximate, intermediate and kʰidi is proximate, very close.
ɖuna is 3pl distant, visible. niyo is distant, invisible.
